Al contrario del pensamiento popular, el texto de Lorem Ipsum no es simplemente texto aleatorio. Tiene sus raices en una pieza cl´sica de la literatura del Latin, que data del año 45 antes de Cristo, haciendo que este adquiera mas de 2000 años de antiguedad. Richard McClintock, un profesor de Latin de la Universidad de Hampden-Sydney en Virginia, encontró una de las palabras más oscuras.

, First of all, we invite you to learn more about the gastronomy of our Llajta!

In the green and fertile valleys of the extensive Q’ochapampa, where various primitive cultures developed such as the Cotas, Chuis and Soras, in which upon the arrival of the Inca Huayna Capac, a vast corn production program was established. It allows us to understand some of the characteristics and peculiarities of the Q’ochala identity and to particularize the characteristics of gastronomy. 
 
The more than 2000 Qollqas (silos) for the storage of corn, built in 1450 in Cotapachi, south of the Municipality of Quillacollo, around the Cotapachi Lagoon, are the guideline to understand the levels of agricultural production of the llajta. For this reason, corn is one of the basic and emblematic products of the Q’ochalas gastronomy in pre-colonial times. 
 
The chronicles allow us to know that the eating habits of the inhabitants of this time were reduced to eating twice a day, consuming cereals, tubers and even pumpkins in Ch’aqui Pacha (dry weather). In the Paray Pacha (rainy season) abundant weeds or salads are eaten, as well as fruits, names by which the seasons of the agricultural year were designated. 
 
As for the ways of preparing food, mention is made of those boiled in water and steamed, buried, k’alapari and kalapurka, grilled and stone-roasted or kankas and k’aspas, khaw’i or sunny, the torrados or jank’as, the flours or j’akus and the dehydrated ones, such as chuños and tuntas.

In the Abya Yala; Before the arrival of the Spaniards, social, cultural, political and economic changes took place, which affected the daily life of the inhabitants of the fertile lands of Q’ochapampa. 
 
Regarding the food issue, there were also modifications in reaction to the processes for preparing food. In this process of miscegenation, the daily consumption of different meats, such as beef, pork, chicken and lamb, was introduced into the diet, in the same way the use of condiments when cooking, such as pepper, nutmeg, saffron, cinnamon , cloves, sugar and other ingredients such as wheat, onions, garlic, parsley, oregano, coriander, vinegars and others. 
 
In this food context, people began to consume fried foods, pickles, the combination of salty and sweet flavor in a single preparation, as well as the consumption of wheat bread and a variety of Spanish pastry products. 
 
The requirements to have appropriate products to prepare the recipes of the gastronomy of the migrants who arrived in these lands, modified the agricultural production practiced by the natives, who had to cultivate new species and varieties of food products.

At the end of the war of independence; In which Andean natives and peasants participated, the Republic of Bolivia arises, but without providing any socio-cultural, political or economic claim to the indigenous population. 
 
The marked European influence on the thinking and sentiment of the new republicans, the changes in the social, political, economic and cultural structures of the cities, is also felt in the mestizo and creole gastronomy that emerged during the colony. 
 
The use of innovative utensils of different shapes and materials to prepare food, as well as the use of other sources of energy for cooking, also make a difference in the flavors and presentation of food. 
 
At this time, it is no longer possible to taste food cooked over a slow fire, as when using the brazier or the q’onchas fueled with firewood, since the use of fuels derived from petroleum or electricity is already emerging. 
 
The nationalist airs, the colonial remnants and the new gastronomic influences of the old world, function and give rise; Beatriz Rossells, a renowned historian, says, “to the emergence of national food” in which it is possible to taste a varied combination of native products and many others from different countries and continents. 
 
Prof. Wilfredo Camacho García (+), renowned anthropologist, said "La llajta Cochabambina deserved the title of Granary of Bolivia for the exuberant production of cereals and other products in its different ecological floors." This aspect made it worthy of the title of "Capital of Bolivian gastronomy", for the exquisite flavor and unmatched seasoning of the Cochabamba people at the time of preparing the variety of dishes on the Cochabambino menu.

The information in this section was obtained from the magazine 
"Misk’i" 
Knowledge and flavors 
cochabambinos
The user preferred not to specify it \n

Our goal with the \"Llajta Comida \" application is to enhance one of the most important qualities of Cochabamba, such as gastronomy, providing the local and visitor population with a tool for their mobile devices so that through it, they have the necessary information so they can learn about food options and the places where they can be found.
Univervidad Mayor de San Simón \nFacultad de Ciencias y Tecnología \nIngeniería de Sistemas
